current_fact.fact_text: On January 1, 1845, the Philippines literally jumped a day forward, skipping December 31, 1844, to realign its calendar with the rest of Asia. For 323 years it had been one day out of sync because of how the first Spanish expedition crossed the globe, meaning an entire country quietly lived in a different yesterday.

episode.title: Morning Drops #14 - Slow Planet
episode.description: A pause. A quiet return to slower rhythms, sparked by a live set under the summer sky. A moment to breathe and settle into the week.

current_fact.match_reason: An entire nation resynchronising its sense of time fits with the episode’s idea of adjusting our internal tempo and finding a calmer planetary rhythm.

queue.fact_text: On the first day of 1900, Britain declared Nigeria a protectorate, formalizing colonial rule over a vast, culturally diverse region in West Africa. This act reshaped borders and identities, setting the stage for both exploitation and later independence movements that would transform the continent.

episode.title: Morning Drops #24 - The Rise Of Afrobeat
episode.description: An exploration of the rise of Afrobeat, tracing its roots and evolution as a genre that blends African rhythms with jazz, funk, and highlife. A celebration of the infectious energy and cultural significance of this influential musical movement.

queue.match_reason: Nigeria’s colonial history and later independence struggles are deeply woven into Afrobeat’s political grooves, making this episode a cultural and musical echo of that turning point.

queue.fact_text: New Year’s Day 1901 marked the official birth of the Commonwealth of Australia, as six British colonies federated into a single nation and Edmund Barton became its first prime minister. This peaceful unification stitched together distant settlements into a new continental identity under one flag.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - Sailing With Germans
episode.description: From the deck of a sailing boat, hosted by Yasmin and her special guests. A week at sea with six Germans, each with their own stories, songs, and ways of moving through the waves. From shared meals to unexpected laughter, from quiet resilience to sun-soaked joy — a collection of voices and tracks that reflect what it means to journey together.
songs: Ben Howard - Keep Your Head Up

queue.match_reason: An entire continent choosing to journey together as one nation mirrors the episode’s imagery of people sharing a boat, stories, and a new collective course.

queue.fact_text: On January 1, 1962, Western Samoa became the first Pacific island nation to regain independence in the 20th century, stepping out from under New Zealand administration. It marked a quiet but powerful shift as Indigenous governance and Samoan identity moved back to the center of political life.

episode.title: Morning Drops #11 - Mediterranean Boat
episode.description: Gaia invites you to embark on a musical voyage across the Mediterranean. Exploring music from different countries shared by people who call them home. A warm, sun-soaked journey through coastal sounds.
songs: Fabrizio De André - Crêuza de mä

queue.match_reason: Islands, sea routes, and the idea of home connect Samoa’s independence to this maritime, border-crossing musical voyage.

queue.fact_text: At the start of 1973, Denmark, Ireland, and the United Kingdom joined the European Economic Community, weaving their economies into a growing experiment in continental cooperation. The move quietly redrew political and cultural relationships across Europe, long before anyone spoke of the European Union as we know it today.

episode.title: Sedna FM #02 - Destination Sedna
episode.description: Continuing the Sedna FM journey together with family and friends! Episode two of the main series — exploring new musical territories and deepening the connection with our listeners. A collective voyage through sound.
songs: Odion Iruoje - Identify With Your Roots
Depeche mode - world in my eyes (Oil Tank Mix)

queue.match_reason: The EEC’s expansion was a journey into a shared ‘destination’ of integration, echoing the episode’s theme of collective voyages across borders and sounds.

queue.fact_text: On New Year’s Day 1995, Austria, Finland, and Sweden formally entered the European Union, bringing forests, fjords, and Alpine valleys into a broader political project. Their accession deepened the EU’s northern character and added new cultural textures to the European tapestry.

episode.title: Morning Drops #22 - Sicilians On The Dolomites
episode.description: Hosted by Yasmin, a musical journey inspired by the mountains. Joined by two special guests, exploring the tracks they've chosen, hearing the stories behind their picks, and discovering the personal memories each song brings to life — a blend of music, voices, and landscapes you can hear.
songs: Florian Pellissier Quintet - Coup de foudre à Thessalonique
Lucio Dalla & Francesco De Gregori - Ma come fanno i marinai

queue.match_reason: The entry of Alpine and Nordic countries into the EU resonates with this mountain-themed episode, both blending high landscapes with cross-border stories.

queue.fact_text: On January 1, 1989, the Montreal Protocol came into force, committing the world to phasing out ozone-depleting chemicals like CFCs. It became a rare example of global environmental cooperation that actually worked, slowly healing the protective ozone layer that shields life from damaging ultraviolet radiation.

episode.title: Morning Drops #23 - Morning Dubs
episode.description: Recorded while still processing Houghton Festival. One of the mornings there, waking up in the woods to a reggae DJ set — no phone signal, just trees, music, and loved ones. A slow selection of reggae, dub, and morning rhythms. Dubs instead of drops. Start your day slow — with space to breathe.
songs: The Gaylads - Joy in the Morning
King Tubby - King Tubby Meets the Rockers Uptown

queue.match_reason: Dub and roots reggae often carry environmental and anti-"Babylon" messages; this woodsy, back-to-nature episode mirrors the treaty’s attempt to protect Earth’s atmospheric ‘roof.’

queue.fact_text: On New Year’s Day 1978, Air India Flight 855, a Boeing 747 departing Bombay, plunged into the Arabian Sea shortly after takeoff due to instrument failure, spatial disorientation, and pilot error. In barely minutes, 213 lives were lost — a stark reminder of how fragile high-tech systems can be when human perception is pushed to its limits.

episode.title: Morning Drops #05 - Electric Shock
episode.description: An energizing episode with electrifying sounds to wake you up and get you moving. High energy tracks that deliver a jolt of musical electricity to start your day.

queue.match_reason: The violent suddenness of the crash and its mix of technology and human error finds a dark echo in this high-voltage rock set, like a jolt that snaps us into awareness.

queue.fact_text: On January 1, 1995, instruments on an oil platform in the North Sea recorded the Draupner wave — a single, towering wall of water nearly 26 meters high. Long dismissed as sailors’ exaggerations, this rare ‘freak wave’ was the first solid proof that rogue giants do erupt from seemingly ordinary seas.

episode.title: Morning Drops #33 - Immerse
episode.description: An analogy between diving, one of Gaia's great passions, and the act of immersing in life itself. A reflection on what happens when we go below the surface: when we let ourselves be fully present. From moments of calm suspension to warm, rhythmic flow, the selection moves like water — fluid, organic, and alive. An invitation to slow down, listen deeper, and float.
songs: Pino D'Angiò - Un Po' d'Uva e un Liquore

queue.match_reason: A mysterious, solitary wave rising from a calm sea fits the episode’s watery textures and its theme of what happens when you go beneath the surface.

queue.fact_text: In the bitter winter of 1781, 1,500 soldiers of the 6th Pennsylvania Regiment mutinied at Morristown, New Jersey, protesting unpaid wages and harsh conditions in what became known as the Pennsylvania Line Mutiny. Their rebellion forced American leaders to confront the human cost of the Revolutionary War and the promises made to ordinary soldiers.

episode.title: Morning Drops #08 - (un)Boxing
episode.description: An episode about breaking free from expectations and labels. Music that helps us unbox ourselves and embrace who we truly are.
songs: Kendrick Lamar - The Blacker the Berry

queue.match_reason: The mutiny was soldiers refusing to stay boxed into unfair treatment, echoing the episode’s theme of breaking out of imposed roles with a defiant, conscious edge.

queue.fact_text: On January 1, 1776, amid the uncertainty of revolution, George Washington raised the Continental Union Flag — an early version of the United States flag — over Prospect Hill. It symbolically stitched together thirteen quarrelsome colonies into a fragile new idea of unity.

episode.title: Morning Drops #01 - Timeless Legacy
episode.description: Gaia guides us through timeless music to start the morning with the right foot! The first episode of the Morning Drops series — classic sounds that never fade.
songs: Roberta Flack - Killing me softly with his song

queue.match_reason: Raising a first national flag is about founding a legacy; this opening Morning Drops episode is likewise a gentle ‘first flag’ for a series of enduring sounds.

queue.fact_text: That same New Year’s Day in 1776, Norfolk, Virginia was deliberately burned during a chaotic clash of the Royal Navy and Continental forces. The city was largely destroyed, demonstrating how a war for independence could consume the very communities it sought to free.

episode.title: Morning Drops #39 - Moving Meditation
episode.description: An episode inspired by how travel helps us see more clearly. Stepping into new places opens the mind, shifts perspective. The music moves through balearic warmth, boogie grooves, world and latin-folk influences, and touches of new wave — a selection built to follow the quiet changes that happen when you're out of your usual rhythm.
songs: España Circo Este - Dormo poco e sogno molto
Talking Heads - This Must Be the Place (Naive Melody)

queue.match_reason: The destruction of a home city and the need to move on connects with this episode’s reflective travel theme and search for new ‘places’ after rupture.

queue.fact_text: On January 1, 1945, the German Luftwaffe launched Operation Bodenplatte, a surprise air offensive meant to cripple Allied air power in one audacious blow. Instead, the operation backfired, costing Germany hundreds of pilots it could not replace and hastening the collapse of its air force.

episode.title: Morning Drops #17 - Steel City
episode.description: Gaia takes us on a short trip through Sheffield's sounds — from electronic textures to raw guitars and sharp storytelling. Four tracks, one city, different edges of the same story.
songs: The Human League - The Sound Of The Crowd

queue.match_reason: Factories, steel, and the machinery of war connect this aerial offensive to Sheffield’s ‘Steel City’ sonic landscape, where industry and conflict echo in electronic and industrial sounds.

queue.fact_text: On New Year’s Day 1725, Johann Sebastian Bach premiered his chorale cantata "Jesu, nun sei gepreiset" (BWV 41), framing the turning of the year with bright trumpet fanfares that return triumphantly at the end. It was designed as a musical arc of gratitude and hope, wrapping a congregation in sound as they stepped into the unknown of a new year.

episode.title: Sedna FM #03 - Beautiful as You Feel
episode.description: An episode about self-acceptance and inner beauty. Music that reminds us we are beautiful as we feel, embracing our authentic selves. Warm, uplifting sounds that celebrate individuality.
songs: The The - this is the day
DCTL - Deep Tannin f(eat Rafael Leafar)

queue.match_reason: A radiant New Year cantata built as a blessing for the year ahead pairs with this warm, uplifting celebration of inner beauty and new beginnings.

queue.fact_text: Just a year later, on New Year’s Day 1726, Bach unveiled another festive New Year cantata, "Herr Gott, dich loben wir" (BWV 16), based on a German Te Deum. It turned liturgy into an intricate tapestry of voices, marking the calendar’s reset with gratitude and intricate musical architecture.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb
episode.description: The first Family & Friends radio episode from Yasmin Sarbaoui and Gaia Parolini. Where it all began — a life soundtrack that launched Sedna FM into the universe. Raw, heartfelt, and full of the energy that defines everything that followed.
songs: Canserbero - De la vida como pelicula, tragedia, comedia y ficcion

queue.match_reason: Bach’s New Year ‘launch’ of a major sacred work mirrors Sedna FM’s own first explosive episode — both are foundational, energetic openings to everything that follows.

queue.fact_text: On January 1, 1945, while the war still raged, a very different kind of international project was about to take shape in Europe — but decades later, the story of unity would be told not with planes and armies, but with trade and treaties. Operation Bodenplatte’s failure hastened the end of old empires and indirectly cleared space for the postwar European experiment that would come.

episode.title: Morning Drops #25 - A Trip-Hop Journey
episode.description: Hosted by friend Lorenzo, a journey through the roots and evolution of trip-hop. From Bristol's early experiments with Massive Attack and Tricky, to DJ Shadow's cinematic sampling in California, and Thievery Corporation's global downtempo grooves in Washington D.C. — exploring how this genre blurred boundaries and reshaped electronic music.
songs: Tricky - Hell Is Round the Corner
DJ Shadow - Midnight in a Perfect World

queue.match_reason: World War II’s devastation paved the way for new, boundary-blurring cultures; trip‑hop arose in that later Europe and sonically collages a world reshaped by the war’s end.

queue.fact_text: On New Year’s Day 2024, a magnitude 7.5 earthquake struck Japan’s Noto Peninsula, toppling homes and triggering landslides that killed more than 500 people. Many victims died when traditional wooden houses collapsed, revealing how seismic forces exploit the smallest structural weaknesses.

episode.title: Morning Drops #19 - Wabi Sabi
episode.description: Wabi-sabi is a story about a handmade mug, a small mistake, and the idea that imperfection can be something to keep—not correct. In this Morning Drop, Gaia shares a moment that didn’t go to plan, and four tracks that echo the same spirit: rough takes, studio accidents, lo-fi textures, and quiet surprises. A soft, thoughtful selection moving between warm electronics, classic riffs, and raw edges.A reminder that not everything needs to be polished. Sometimes, it’s better that way.

queue.match_reason: The earthquake’s tragic reminder of fragility stands in stark contrast to wabi‑sabi’s gentle embrace of imperfection, inviting a deeper reflection on what breaks and what we choose to mend.

queue.fact_text: New Year’s Day also marks the quiet anniversaries of nations whose calendars once defined the seas: Ferdinand Magellan reached the Philippines in 1521, inadvertently setting its clocks a day adrift from Asia for centuries. His voyage stitched the first full circle around Earth, proving our planet could be navigated as one continuous world.

episode.title: Morning Drops #32 - A Weekend In London
episode.description: Recorded in London, marking a weekend reunion between Gaia and Yasmin. A selection inspired by London's energy, seen through the eyes of two inseparable friends — music from concerts, club nights, and long walks across town. Four tracks to ease you into the week at the right pace.
songs: Jimmy Castor Bunch - It's Just Begun
The Asphodells - Late Flowering Lust (Phil Kieran Remix)

queue.match_reason: Magellan’s global loop foreshadows the hyper-connected London of this episode, where sounds from across the world meet in one city over a single wandering weekend.

queue.fact_text: On January 1, 1801 and 1901, astronomers and politicians alike were marking new beginnings — but for the Philippines, that date is forever tied to the decision in 1845 to delete a day from its calendar. The country’s three-century-long temporal ‘glitch’ is a quiet reminder that even time zones are human stories laid over a spinning rock.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.

queue.match_reason: Rewriting an entire country’s calendar is a giant act of collective ‘learning’ about timekeeping, mirroring the episode’s exploration of how we adjust our mental maps and live with confusion and correction.

queue.fact_text: Across centuries, New Year’s Day has been chosen for turning points not just in law and war, but also in sound: Bach’s New Year cantatas once opened the year in Leipzig the way a concert or playlist might today. His carefully crafted arcs of tension and release show that even in 1725 and 1726, people welcomed the unknown of a new year with music, not just resolutions.

episode.title: Sedna FM #04 - Queen of Spades
episode.description: Tuning in from the planet of irrational love. Exploring love's most vulnerable side — the kind that awakens the child within us. A diverse music selection ranging from electric blues to downtempo, soul, and jazz. A tribute to the feeling that has moved artists to create the most beautiful works. Love makes us vulnerable, and there is no art without vulnerability.

Queens of the stone age - Make it wit chu
Etta James - I'd Rather Go Blind
Eric Clapton - Have you ever loved a woman

queue.match_reason: Bach’s New Year music was an emotional ritual at the threshold of the year, much like this episode’s vulnerable love‑soaked soundtrack is a ritual of feeling at day’s end.

published.fact_text: In 1801, Italian astronomer and priest Giuseppe Piazzi spotted a tiny moving point of light that turned out to be Ceres — the first and largest known object in the asteroid belt, and now classified as a dwarf planet. For a time it was even considered a new planet, quietly reshaping humanity’s map of the Solar System at the dawn of the 19th century.

episode.title: Morning Drops #03 - Space Shift
episode.description: Gaia invites you to shift your mindset with a simple yet powerful reflection: What if we saw emptiness not as a void but as space to create? An energising and feel-good selection of tracks, the perfect way to ease into your day and set the tone for the week ahead.
songs: Willy J Healey - Woke Up Smiling
The Strokes - You Only Live Once

published.match_reason: A literal ‘space shift’: the discovery of Ceres expanded our sense of cosmic space, fitting the episode’s theme of reimagining emptiness as creative potential.

published.fact_text: On January 1, 1998, Argentinian physicist Juan Maldacena published his groundbreaking paper on the AdS/CFT correspondence, proposing a deep link between gravity in curved space-time and quantum field theories without gravity. This bold idea suggested that our universe might be describable by a kind of hologram, inspiring decades of research into the nature of reality.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

published.match_reason: Both the AdS/CFT correspondence and this episode ask us to rethink what’s ‘real’—whether it’s spacetime as a hologram or our lives mediated through screens and networks.

published.fact_text: In 1739, French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier stumbled upon Bouvet Island, a tiny volcanic speck in the South Atlantic that is often called the most remote island on Earth. Surrounded by treacherous seas and cloaked in ice, it remains uninhabited — a lonely outpost at the edge of the human map.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas
episode.description: Yasmin's friend Caroline takes us beyond the polar circle, into the Arctic waters of Norway, where orcas and humpback whales gather each winter. A personal journey shaped by a quiet obsession with orcas, from Patagonia to the icy fjords of the north. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

published.match_reason: Remote, icy seas connect Bouvet Island with the Arctic waters of the orca dives; both evoke cold horizons, isolation, and fragile life at Earth’s edges.

published.fact_text: On New Year's Day 1818, an anonymous novel titled "Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus" appeared in London, quietly revolutionizing literature. Mary Shelley’s tale of a scientist who assembles life from dead matter helped invent science fiction, asking how far human curiosity and responsibility should reach.

Exploring the artistry of musicians who craft alter-egos and parallel realities to experiment with new dimensions of their identity. It's not about hiding who they are — it's about expanding who they can be.
